articles.headline: Oil Prices Slip Below $70 a Barrel
articles.snippet: Oil prices dropped below $70 a barrel for the first time in 16 months Thursday, prompting the OPEC cartel to call for an emergency meeting next week.
articles.abstract: Oil prices dropped below $70 a barrel for the first time in 16 months Thursday, prompting the OPEC cartel to call for an emergency meeting next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices dropped below $70 a barrel for the first time in 14 months Thursday, prompting the OPEC cartel to call for an emergency meeting next week to establish some stability in prices that have plummeted recently after rising for months.

articles.headline: Google’s Net (and Stock) Rise Sharply
articles.snippet: Third-quarter profit increased 26 percent to $1.35 billion, a strong showing that might be enough to reassure jittery investors.
articles.abstract: Third-quarter profit increased 26 percent to $1.35 billion, a strong showing that might be enough to reassure jittery investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For months, Google has promised investors that the company’s online advertising system would do relatively well in an economic downturn. On Thursday, it showed evidence that it may be able to deliver on that promise.

articles.headline: Banks Fail, and So Can Bailouts
articles.snippet: The government’s latest bailout plan could help restore trust in the markets, if the government makes sure that the cash only goes to banks that are in decent shape.
articles.abstract: The government’s latest bailout plan could help restore trust in the markets, if the government makes sure that the cash only goes to banks that are in decent shape.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trust is a precious thing, and the banks still don’t have much of it. Not from the public, and not from one another.

articles.headline: G.M. Merger Talks With Chrysler Said to Intensify
articles.snippet: Discussions between General Motors and Chrysler are said to be gaining momentum, as both sides want to reach an agreement within the next two to three weeks.
articles.abstract: Discussions between General Motors and Chrysler are said to be gaining momentum, as both sides want to reach an agreement within the next two to three weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Rick Wagoner is running short of time and options to save General Motors and salvage his legacy as leader of the world’s biggest automaker.

articles.headline: In Downturn, Families Strain to Pay Tuition
articles.snippet: With the unemployment rate rising and a recession mentality gripping the country, more families are applying for federal aid for students attending college.
articles.abstract: With the unemployment rate rising and a recession mentality gripping the country, more families are applying for federal aid for students attending college.
articles.lead_paragraph: In difficult dinner-table conversations, college students and their parents are revisiting how to pay tuition as personal finances weaken and lenders get tough.

articles.headline: Courts Compound Pain of China’s Tainted Milk
articles.snippet: Tainted infant formula is the latest in a long string of food and drug safety problems that have exposed corruption among China’s regulators.
articles.abstract: Tainted infant formula is the latest in a long string of food and drug safety problems that have exposed corruption among China’s regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  The first sign of trouble was powder in the baby’s urine. Then there was blood. By the time the parents took their son to the hospital, he had no urine at all.

articles.headline: Rivals’ Visions Differ on Unleashing Innovation
articles.snippet: The presidential candidates’ visions for sharpening the nation’s competitive edge are strikingly different.
articles.abstract: The presidential candidates’ visions for sharpening the nation’s competitive edge are strikingly different.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the United States dominated the technological revolution sweeping the globe. The nation’s science and engineering skills produced vast gains in productivity and wealth, powered its military and made it the de facto world leader.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and Cornelia Dean

articles.headline: Investigators Said to Take Closer Look at Lehman
articles.snippet: People close to the investigations say prosecutors are examining events leading to the investment bank’s collapse and subsequent bankruptcy filing.
articles.abstract: People close to the investigations say prosecutors are examining events leading to the investment bank’s collapse and subsequent bankruptcy filing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors from three jurisdictions have stepped up their investigations into the collapse of the investment bank Lehman Brothers, issuing at least a dozen subpoenas including one to the chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., people close to the matter said Friday.

articles.headline: Rape Victims’ Words Help Jolt Congo Into Change
articles.snippet: Congo, it seems, is finally facing its rape problem, which has been called the worst sexual violence in the world.
articles.abstract: Congo, it seems, is finally facing its rape problem, which has been called the worst sexual violence in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUKAVU, Congo  Honorata Kizende looked out at the audience and began with a simple, declarative sentence.
